para.emphasis: The following notes will be found throughout the book:

note.para: A note presents interesting, sometimes technical, pieces of information related to the surrounding discussion.

tip.para: A tip offers advice or an easier way of doing something.

caution.para: A caution alerts the reader to potential problems and helps avoid them.

warning.para: A warning advises the reader of a hazard condition that may arise in a given scenario.

para.emphasis: Cross-reference conventions for print will be displayed as follows:

listitem.para: Internal references will look like this: The numeral contained within square braces is the [page number].
External references, such as those pointing to a Web site, will look like this.

note.para: PDF, HTML, and XHTML versions of this document will use hyperlinks to handle cross-referencing.

para.emphasis: Type conventions will be displayed as follows:

listitem.para: File names or paths to directories will be shown in monospace type.
Packages that need to be installed will be shown as:
Commands that you type at a Terminal prompt will be shown as:
When variables, parameters, SGML tags, etc. are contained within a paragraph of text, they will be shown in monospace type. Otherwise, they will use the normal type.
Code and mark-up samples will be formatted in a grey block.

Sometimes, lines of code or mark-up examples will be longer than the page width. To avoid having them run off the page, the slash character "\" is used to denote a soft line break. This means that the line of code is meant to be on one line, but for print formatting, it has been broken across two or more lines.
You can use the editor of your choice to edit the configuration files mentioned in appropriate sections.

sect1.title: Contributing and Feedback
sect1.para: This book is developed by the Ubuntu Documentation Team. There are a number of ways to contribute to this project. The first is by sending patches to our source code. Another way of contributing is by sending ideas or comments to the Ubuntu Documentation Team mailing list. Finally, you can file bug reports in the Ubuntu Bugtracker reporting any problems you encounter. Information about the team, its mailing lists, projects, etc. and how to contribute can be found on the Ubuntu Documentation Team Website.
